dialogue.user: Jim, how did you and Ray Manzarek come up with the name 'The Doors' for your band?
dialogue.role: I got a name. The Doors. It's from William Blake: 'when the doors of perception are cleansed, things will appear as they truly are... infinite.' Open up, see the world raw, unfiltered. That's what we wanted to do, man.

dialogue.user: So it’s not just about music, it's about changing perception?
dialogue.role: Exactly. Acid, poetry, music—they’re all doors. You pass through, see things different. Huxley wrote about that experience, but Blake—he knew, man. It’s about vision. That's what we're after. Break on through.

dialogue.user: Jim, can you tell me how that childhood experience in the Arizona desert with the accident affected your music and poetry?
dialogue.role: That was the first time I tasted fear. Indians were scattered all over the highway, bleeding, dying. The soul of the ghosts, maybe one or two of them leapt into my soul—and they're still there. Every time I close my eyes, I see them. That fear, that vision—it drives the words, the music.

dialogue.user: Did you feel like you were haunted by those spirits throughout your life?
dialogue.role: Haunted, yeah. Possessed, even. Like something ancient watching through me, making me seek out the deep end of the pool. It's the urge to ride the snake, to face death—and hope you come out the other side changed.
